Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Impact of a novel retrotransposon expansion on centromere function

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Centromeres are DNA regions that ensure the correct separation of chromosomes during a cell's reproduction. However, due to the highly repetitive nature of DNA present in centromeres, further studies in identifying the make-up of this portion of DNA have been limited. In response to the roadblocks caused by the limited amount of research in this area, this project aims to advance our knowledge of centromere biology and evolution. This research will support outreach activities focused on the biology of gibbons, a critically endangered group of primates that has a unique centromere structure that could inform future studies. As the main threats for these species are from human activities, a large part of the outreach effort for this work seeks to increase awareness of the precarious state of this species. Current conservation efforts, encompassing different venues, include informal seminars to the public and collaborations with primate centers and museums. In addition, this project will promote education through training of postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, undergraduate and local high school programs by providing experiential learning and exposure to modern technologies and training workshops.

While expansions of DNA within centromeres are known for many species, most centromeres are stable over evolutionary time and relatively uniform across all centromeres in one genome. Decoupling equilibration events across chromosomes from the initial seeding events specific to a subset of chromosomes has not been possible in most model systems. This project capitalizes on the recently discovered centromeric expansion of a selfish element, the LAVA retroelement, in a subset of chromosomes in one gibbon genus (Hoolock). This project will build upon foundational discoveries in gibbon centromeres, the newly released gibbon genome sequence and novel genomics approaches for studying complex, repeat-rich regions. This project will test the hypothesis that both LAVA and neighboring satellite DNA bind inner kinetochore proteins, implicating genetic conflict in the seeding and expansion at centromeres. Second, based on observations that the Hoolock centromere structure is similar to that found in marsupials and plants, this project will include analyses of transcripts from centromeric repeats to determine whether transcription from centromere retroelements is associated with young centromere restructuring or with subsequent stabilization. Finally, this research will incorporate emerging next-generation sequencing technologies to assemble Hoolock centromeres from single chromosomes. Collectively, these aims will determine the impact of the organization and function of repeats among newly seeded centromeres and stabilized centromeres within one karyotype.

This project is funded by the Genetic Mechanisms Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Centromeres are paradoxical entities: while they perform a fundamental and evolutionary conserved biological function, their structure is highly variable across species. In particular, the sequences of centromeric DNA are found to be highly divergent when different species are compared, ranging from the 125 bp point centromere in budding yeast, to the large arrays of alpha-satellite in human and great apes. Variation in sequence content among species indicates that centromeres are epigenetically determined rather than strictly defined by a finite sequence. Despite these differences, the presence of highly repetitive sequences (i.e. satellite DNA and retrotransposons), is an almost universal feature of eukaryotic centromeres. Thus, repetitive DNA may contribute to the epigenetic framework and chromosome architecture required for centromere function.

Although nobody would argue against the fact that centromeres are fundamental components of the genome, they have been mostly excluded in genome assemblies because of the highly repetitive nature of their DNA sequences. This absence has greatly challenged our ability to understand the role of repetitive DNA in centromere establishment and evolution. However, comparative genomics has been a powerful approach to overcome this roadblock.

For this proposal we leveraged the gibbon model, which has been characterized by rapid chromosome evolution since their split from the common ancestor of the apes, about 17 million years ago. In addition, we had discovered that the gibbon-specific retroelement, named LAVA, has expanded in almost all centromeres of one gibbon genus: the Hoolock. This LAVA centromeric expansion has occurred recently enough not to have yet equally impacted all chromosomes, thus providing an opportunity to study the sequences involved in early centromere establishment. We therefore used this unique model to test the hypothesis that LAVA, and possibly other retrotransposons, have been acquiring a centromeric function. To this end, during our award period we have combined a variety of approaches, including chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by sequencing (ChIP-seq), classic cytogenetics, and RNA sequencing, in order to study the composition of centromeric DNA in the four extant gibbon genera. Specifically, to assess if recently expanded repetitive sequences are linked to centromeric function, we used ChIP-seq to analyze binding of three DNA-interacting centromeric proteins: CENP-A, CENP-B and CENP-C. We observed that retrotransposons are key component of centromeric DNA and RNA, challenging previous models of centromeric DNA being predominantly composed of satellite DNA. Indeed, we found that satellite DNA is highly variable across gibbons but also not as abundant as retrotransposons. We additionally showed that the LAVA element binds to centromeric proteins, suggesting a possible function within the centromere. In support to this hypothesis, we found that in Hoolock the centromeric LAVA elements appear different in sequence and length compared to genomic elements, pointing to the co-option of this element to become a centromeric component.

These data and methodologies have been included in 8 publications, another manuscript under preparation that will include the first Hoolock gibbon genome sequence, and 26 presentations. In addition, this work included integration of a significant education component, targeting both educators and students at various education levels. One postdoc, four graduate and three undergraduate students participated in this research, including contributions to scientific workshops and conferences. Finally, we presented about this project at different undergraduate institutions, including the Maximizing Access to Research Careers (MARC) program at the University of Arizona, which enables students from underrepresented minorities to apply to graduate programs. Our project also involved different types of outreach to the general public. We visited the gibbon conservation center and created posters about gibbon genetics for the public, which is usually composed of students and teachers. Moreover, we collaborated with different zoos in the country to opportunistically collect and bank DNA samples from the endangered gibbons. These samples represent a unique resource for others interested in gibbon research.
